response.answer_text: Does time exist? To answer this question, we first need to understand what time is. For one, time is not the measurement of duration. Time is fundamental. Time determines duration. Get ready for a completely new way of thinking about time. One which no philosopher or scientists has ever considered. This is an actual definition of what time is. Let me start with an analogy. Does movement exist? Yes I know things move, but is movement a physical thing? Can we see movement or can we only see things move? Can movement go faster, or make things move faster? Can we touch movement? Weight it? No! Can we measure it? No, but we can measure how far things move. Movement exist as a physical phenomena. It's something that physical things do. Well, so is time. Time is a term describing temporal motion. That's motion from the past to the future. From the present moment, to the next. You see, our universe exists in a 2 dimensional fabric which I call temp-space. One temporal dimension and one spatial dimension. We move through the spatial dimension and we time through the temporal dimension. So time is a physical phenomena similar to motion. It's temporal motion. Time doesn't move. Time is not something we move through. Time is not the rate of motion through space or the duration of events. Time is the motion of objects through the temporal dimension. Temporal distances are not like spatial distances. Instead of meters and feet, we have seconds, minutes, hours, etc. These are actual physical distances things move through an actual physical dimension. Distances which we can physically measure with the aid of clocks, which are basically temporal tape measures. It's the rate at which things time, which determine the duration of events. Our temporal velocity determines the speed at which atomic, biological and mechanical processes occur and as I said earlier, our temporal velocity is inversely proportional to our spatial velocity. This is why clocks tick slower the faster you move through space. Not just our wall clocks but our biological clocks as well. We actually age slower. I'm gonna take a break here, but feel free to read my other answers on time, attached below. Zane Scheepers's answer to How can gravity slow down time, if time isn’t something tangible you can touch? The speed of light is 300,000 km per second. Why does light not travel faster/slower? Can we describe the nature of time?

“Does time exist?” No, time doesn’t exist in an absolute sense. What we can perceive is order(causality/simultaneity) of events. And this perception is based on the light path that illuminates the events and reflects this information back to the eyes of the observer. Time can thus only be described in terms of the simultaneity/causality of events as described by the light path. Using these events, we can define time in a relative sense. For example, if I say that the sun rises at 6 A.M, then what I mean is this “The pointing of the small hand of my watch to 6 and the occurrence of my shadow at a particular point of space (which you can choose arbitrarily in the absence of standards), in my immediate locality, are simultaneous events.” Now, note that I say ‘in my immediate locality’. This is because the finite speed of light(which is an experimentally observed fact) would not cause any significant effects on causality for very small distances(given the high speed of light). I cannot use the following definition: “The pointing of the small hand of my watch to 6 and the appearance of the sun on the horizon, are simultaneous events”, because there would be significant effects on causality, given the distance involved. This definition is thus not independent of the observer. Common Time and Synchronization of Stationary Clocks So far, we’ve defined a ‘local time’ for myself(A) and the observer at the horizon(B).We have not defined a ‘common time’ for A and B, for the latter cannot be defined at all unless we establish by definition that the ‘time’ required by light to travel from A to B equals the ‘time’ it requires to travel from B to A. Let a ray of light start at the ‘A time’ tA from A towards B, let it at the ‘B time’ tB be reflected at B in the direction of A, and arrive again at A at the ‘A time t′A. When the observer A sees the time in B’s clock at ‘A time’ t′A, he is seeing the ‘B time’ at tB, even though the B time has by then changed to something else. Let’s clarify this with an example: Let’s assume for example, that the time taken for light to travel from A to B (and B to A) is 1 minute. Let’s also assume that when observed by a third observer who is in rest with respect to both A and B, ‘A time’ and ‘B time’ are separated by 10 minutes. So when ‘A time’ is 6 A.M, ‘B time’ is 6:10 A.M. Then, let at ‘A time’ 6 A.M(tA), a light ray start from A. Let it reach B and be reflected back at ‘B time’ 6:11 A.M(tB). Let the reflected ray reach A again at ‘A time’ 6:02 A.M(t′A). Then, at 6:02 AM ‘A time’, A sees a ‘B time’ of 6:11 AM, even though the ‘B time’ has changed to 6:12 AM. So now(at ‘A time’ 6:02 AM), A changes his time to 6:11 AM. This is the new A time. Now, in the above example, the time taken for light to travel from A to B is taken as 1 minute(which is huge for normal distances) and is comparable to the time difference between the two clocks. And yet the difference between the two clocks has been reduced from 10 minutes to 1 minute.(which is the time taken by light to travel from A to B). In most cases, given the speed of light, the time taken for light would much much less than the time difference between the two clocks and the synchronization would be accurate to parts of a millionth of a second and the two observers would see roughly the same time. It is only when huge distances(astronomical distances for example) are involved, that the clock synchronization process introduces huge errors. Now lets see what happens when the time taken for light to travel from A to B is not the same as that from B to A. Let’s suppose that the time taken for light to travel from A to B is 1 minute and B to A is 2 minutes. In this case, synchronizing A with B will introduce an error of 1 minute, while synchronizing B with A will introduce an error of 2 minutes. However, you might ask how it matters as long as the time difference between them remains constant. The problem starts when you introduce a third clock to be synchronized with both A and B. In this case, synchronizing C with A will introduce a different error than when C is synchronized with B. Hence we will never be able to synchronize more than two clocks. This is why we need to define the time taken for light to travel from A to B to be the same as that from B to A. One might wonder why the above equality needs to be defined rather than being experimentally verified. Remember that to experimentally verify the speed of light from A to B, we need the clocks at A and B to be synchronized in the first place!!! This is a circular requirement. Hence there is no alternative but to define the time taken for light to travel from A to B to be the same as that from B to A. Once the clocks are synchronized, we can write: tB−tA=t′A−tB The above equality can also be written as: ABv=ABv where v is the velocity for light traveling from A to B(and B to A) In agreement with experimental results, which find the velocity of light to be the same in all inertial frames(or put another way, no relative movement between the earth and the light), we assume this speed v=c - the speed of light in free space. Thus c=2ABt′A−tA Thus we have now defined what is to be understood by synchronous stationary clocks located at different places, and have obtained a definition of ‘simultaneity’ and of ‘time.’ The “time” of an event is that which is given simultaneously with the event by a stationary clock located at the place of the event(in the above example A’s clock , the event being reading B’s time at the place where A is located), this clock being synchronous, for all time determinations, with a specified stationary clock(B’s clock, with which A tries to synchronize his clock). It is necessary to understand what is meant by the phrase ‘for all time determinations’. It means that once the two stationary clocks are synchronized, they remain synchronized forever. This is not possible with clocks that are moving with respect to each other. Even if you synchronize them when they are at rest, they drift apart when they are subjected to relative motion, as I have discussed here: Nikhil Panikkar's answer to If all motion is relative, then how can any speed or light speed be an absolute constant? Let’s say two objects are traveling towards each other and both are traveling at 0.75c, wouldn't their relative speed exceed the speed of light? So, to summarize, time is: Dependent on the Causality/Simultaniety of eventsDependent on the light path taken, that illuminates the events and reflects this information back to the eyes of the observer.Dependent on the space where from where we observe the events.Now that we have an idea about what time is, I would like to discuss some common fallacies associated with the Special Theory of Relativity and its notion of time. Fallacies Fallacy - 1 - “It is possible to hypothetically Freeze time and Define an Absolute ‘Now’ “ A lot of people have this notion that it is possible to define an absolute moment of time - which they call ‘Now’ - by ‘freezing time’ across ‘all’ inertial frames. According to them, only the perception of now is different. A common example given to support this notion is the example of a cosmological event, like a supernova exploding. According to this notion, if a star which is 10 light years away, goes supernovae right this instant, we won't know anything for the next ten years. That doesn't change the fact that it's going supernovae at the ‘present moment’. Explanation - The first fallacy associated with this description is the notion that freezing time across ‘all’ ‘inertial frames, is somehow physically different from introducing an additional inertial frame, from which we observe these other frames. Any time you compare n frames from the outside, it is physically equivalent to introducing an n+1 th frame, from which you compare the n frames. And this process can be continued ad infinitum.If you are saying that the phrase ‘freezing frames’ is somehow different from introducing an additional external frame, then you are only playing with words, as physically there is no difference.(That’s why I use the word ‘equivalent’) You can’t compare n inertial frames from the outside without introducing an n+1 th frame. Whatever you describe from this n+1th frame is valid only from that frame’s point of view. It has no universal significance. So for example, if you try to send a light signal to freeze clocks across inertial frames ‘Now’, then that ‘now’ has meaning only in your frame. By the time, the light reaches the other frames, it is not ‘now’ for you. It is already in the past for you.This is a true even if all the inertial frames are stationary and equidistant from your frame. If the frames are stationarity with respect to each other and equidistant, it might be possible to freeze times across all other n frames. However, time has not frozen in your inertial frame. It has flowed past your ‘Now’. This is something one must understand thoroughly, that the relativity of simultaneity does not require inertial frames to be in motion with respect to each other. It can also occur even when the inertial frames are stationary with respect to each other. This is because the relativity of simultaneity is a consequence of the finite speed of light. As such it is the most fundamental relativistic effect. It is present even where other relativistic effects like time dilation and length contraction are not. If the other frames are not equidistant or stationary then the light signal will take different times to reach each frame and you’ll never be able to freeze times across them. Coming to the supernova example mentioned earlier, saying that there is some universal ‘now’ or ‘present’ moment somewhere out there is just another way of saying that there is a universal clock out there, in some frame of reference, that can see the supernova happening at the same instant as that of an observer in the frame of reference of that supernova, which is not possible given the finite speed of light -which is an experimentally proven fact. If you still think that it is possible to define an ‘absolute moment of time, then try the following fun exercise: Give me a scientific description(that is, one which can be used for making deductions and measurements) of a moment of absolute time without using any reference frames or events.. And if you can’t give such a description, then it doesn’t exist from a scientific point of view. Fallacy - 2 - “Now, is our current temporal position. Time isn't something that flows. The word time is a term describing our motion through the temporal dimension. We time from one moment to the next. From the past to the future. Everything in the universe is timing, but, at different temporal velocities.” Explanation: This is the same fallacy as above, in a slightly more sophisticated terminology. It talks of absolute time being perceived by observers in terms of different time scales. How do we compare time scales? Let’s consider that you are comparing the orbital velocities of two bodies in the solar system. How do you know that the orbital velocity of one object is not the same that of the other? Answer: With the help of events. So for example, an Earth solar year is not qualitatively different from a Mercury solar year. It is the time when either completes a revolution around the Sun. So how do we know that they are on different time scales? We do so by comparing the location of Earth and Mercury in space. Without the comparison in space(in other words, an event), there is no meaning of the term relative time scale. In fact, there is no meaning of the term absolute time scale too, because qualitatively there is no difference between Earth completing one revolution and Mercury completing one revolution. So for example, if I decide to mark my current location in space and decide to call the moment when I reach the same location after completing a revolution around the earth as ‘Now’, does it have any meaning different from that of another person doing the same on another planet? No. Because both are qualitatively the same. And if you are arguing that there is a difference, then you’re assigning a uniqueness to a spot in space - which is highly questionable. This is because space is again dependent on time. We are constantly moving through space. In empty space, we decide our location in relation to distant stars, which themselves are moving, but appear to be stationary because of the distance. If I’m in empty space, without any astronomical objects to observe, then does the term ‘time scale’ have any meaning? No. Does the term ‘location in space’ have any meaning. No. Hence there is no absolute time or space. Both are relative to each other. Fallacy - 3 - “Time is felt”. Explanation: This is the most fundamental fallacy of the three. In fact, It is this fallacy that leads to the above two fallacies. According to this fallacy, absolute time is intuitively ‘felt’ without any reference to events, and it is relative time that is observed with respect to events. Since absolute time is ‘felt’, it exists, even if it can’t be described. A common question that is asked to support the above fallacy is the following question: “What feels longer? Six hours of sleep or six hours of wakefullness”? The idea is that both are six hours long, but we perceive it on different time scales. So there is an ‘absolute’(because we are talking about the same observer) time scale(of six hours), but we ‘travel’ through them in different ‘temporal’ velocities(perceptions). A counter-question to ask in this respect would be the following:”Which feels longer? Three hours of a written examination or three hours on the operation table(when you are given anesthasia and when you drift in and out of consciousness)”? The answer is three hours on the operation table. The reason is that we ‘feel’ time with respect to biological events. When you have six hours of deep sleep you are not observing any biological events. Hence you don’t have any perception of time, while you do, when you are waking through six hours. When you are in a state of semi-consciousness on an operation table, you are subconsciously observing biological events(like your heartbeat, breathing, hunger). This gives you a longer perception of time than when you are fully focused on answering your question paper and have subconsciously cut out any distractions - both external or biological. Historically this is how humans have discovered days getting shorter in winter and longer in summer. The events of sun rising and setting are not qualitatively different in summer or winter, but when they fail to align with our natural cycle of sleep and hunger, we realize that there is a relative difference between the same events(our desire to have a meal or falling asleep) and discover that days are getting shorter in winter and longer in summer. If the differences between biological events and astronomical events were small, we would not even notice the time difference. Hence when you are ‘feeling’ time you are actually subconsciously observing biological events. Without biological events, you have no sense of time. Fallacy - 4 - “The Big Bang can be used to Measure Absolute Time” Explanation: Measurements with respect to the Big Bang are not absolute. While all observers in the universe will agree on the Big Bang as the first event of the observable universe(in other words, causality), they will measure different times from the event. However, there are two experimentally verified facts that come in handy for cosmologists: The speed at which Galaxies are moving through space is very small(around 500–600kmph) compared to the speed of light.The anisotropy(that is the variation with respect to direction) of the Universe’s expansion is very small(one in hundred thousand). [1][2]Both are verified using the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation. As a result, we can neglect the relative variation in the speeds of observers and the relative skew in terms of position in space. This is similar to how we can neglect relativistic effects in Classical Mechanics because of the low speeds and distances involved, with respect to light. But this does not mean that relativistic effects don’t exist. Hence for all ‘practical’ purposes(cosmological ones, that is) we can neglect relativistic effects and consider the time measured from the Big Bang to be a measure of absolute time.(This is how for example, the age of the universe is calculated.). However, from a strictly theoretical viewpoint, time measured from the Big Bang is not absolute. Also note that the ‘absolute’ measurements given by CMB radiation are valid only for cosmological purposes. For example, the error given with respect to the age of the universe is 0.020 billion years!!![3] This is virtually useless for any other purpose than cosmology. The only thing that Big Bang provides is an origin for time. All observers agree on the Big Bang being the first event in the observable universe. However, each observer measures a different time from the occurrence of the Big Bang. Summary There is no absolute ‘time’.Time is dependent and is measured with respect to causality/simultaniety of eventsTime is dependent on the space from which we observe the events and space, in turn, is dependent on the causality of events that we observe from that space. Thus space and time are not independent of each other.A rhetorical description of time, using phrases like “Time is Now” is useless from a scientific viewpoint. Absolute time cannot be defined in a manner that can be used to make deductions or measurements. And anything that can’t be described in a scientific manner, does not exist from a scientific point of view.Conclusion The above answer has been written from the perspective of time in physics, which is based on the theory of Special Relativity, where space and time are not by themselves absolute , but spacetime is absolute. There is also the theory of General Relativity where spacetime is not absolute and can be influenced by matter. There is also the Quantum Mechanics framework, where the temporal spread of a particle’s wave function can be greater than the separation in time between events A and B. This means that the causal order of A and B cannot be always be distinguished by a quantum particle such as a photon. Some theories treat this as an asymmetry between space and time, where conservation laws operate in a different manner over time than over space.[4][5] But this is still a work in progress. Then there is the topic of Time Flow(Arrow of time), which discusses whether it is possible to reverse the order of states in a process. This has to be dealt with in a Thermodynamics framework(entropy).[6] There is also the field of Time Perception, which occurs in the field of neuroscience and psychology and this uses a completely different framework than that of physics.[7] . Footnotes[1] Analysis of cosmic microwave background radiation shows universe is isotropic[2] Theoretical Overview of Cosmic Microwave Background Anisotropy[3] Planck 2018 results. VI. Cosmological parameters[4] Quantum asymmetry between time and space[5] The quantum theory of time, the block universe, and human experience[6] Entropy (arrow of time) - Wikipedia[7] Time perception - Wikipedia

I have not a great knowledge in Physics but I've read some of McTaggart. In perhaps his most famous work, the paper “The Unreality of Time,” McTaggart argues that time, as we know it, cannot possibly exist.  In his paper, McTaggart defends a number of premises to prove his conclusion.  This week’s post will focus on one of those premises: that the past, present, and future cannot exist. We have two main ways of thinking about events in time.  First, we can think of them as being in the past, present, or future, and McTaggart calls this the “A series.”  As I am typing this, I am aware that this piece will be published in the future.  In a few days, it will be getting published in the present.  In a few weeks, it will have been published in the past.  The other way to think about events is in terms of how they relate to each other.  For instance, I was born before Barack Obama was elected president.  This statement is as true today as it was a week ago, a year ago, or even a century ago.  It will be true tomorrow, the day after, and in the year 10,000 as well.  No matter what, the relationship between my birth and Obama’s election simply will not change.  McTaggart calls this the “B series.”  As you may have noticed, events in the A series change (from future to present to past), but events in the B series do not change at all (they simply are either earlier or later than each other, no matter what). McTaggart argues that time cannot exist in terms of the A series.  In other words, there is no such thing as the past, present, or future.  We may naturally think and experience the world that way, but that does not mean that’s how nature really is.  That just means our brains alter how we perceive the world in order to make it more easily understandable.  If you don’t think our brains would really do that to us, just go and search for “the cutaneous rabbit,” or “Orwellian and Stalinesque revision.”  Our brain literally alters how we perceive events in time in order to make things easier to understand – the notion of the past, present, and future may be just another one of those alterations. To prove there is no A series, we must first agree that no single event can simultaneously possess the qualities of being in the past, present, and the future.  Every event, when analyzed from a specific moment, is (relative to that moment) in the past, the present, or the future.  If this weren’t the case, then there wouldn’t be any meaningful way to distinguish between the words “past”, “present”, and “future” – they’d all mean the same thing.  So, in order for the A series to exist, events must be in the past, the present, or the future, but never more than one. The problem, now, is determining whether an event is in the past, the present, or the future.  How do you determine which label to apply?  Every event, depending on when you look at it, is in the past, present, and future.  As I write this now, Obama was elected in the past. But why should I prefer this moment in time as my way of deciding what label to apply to Obama’s election?  Why not look at it from the year 2000 and say Obama’s election is in the future?  After all, according to the A theory, the past is just as real as the present.  Why would we arbitrarily give preference to the present moment when deciding if an event is in the past or future?  Even if you do want to defend that arbitrary choice, the same problem still arises.  Let’s say you do believe that we should use the present to determine whether an event is past, present, or future.  Re-read that last sentence.  We have to use the present in order to determine an event’s relationship to the present?  To do that, we again have to assume the existence of the past, present, and future.  Now we’re in a circle.  We need to assume the existence of a present moment in order to determine if an event is past, present, or future.  But why make that assumption?  Because it just feels like there’s a present moment?  That’s not good enough – recall the cutaneous rabbit and Orwellian/Stalinesque revisions.  We cannot blindly assume that our experience of a present moment is objective and true.  Every moment feels like the present moment.  Our brain regularly lies to us about temporal matters, and that feeling of a “now” may just be another one of those lies. Think of your life like a timeline.  If McTaggart is correct, then our life isn’t actually a steady point (the present) going from start to finish on that line.  Rather, it’s the whole line.  The whole thing is “real” in some strange, timeless way.  In resume , having a life with no time dependecy is a virtue.

Yes time exists. It exists absolutely because everything can be referred back to the Big Bang, e.g. the origin of the universe. All events exist within this universe by definition and can be ordered with respect to space-time, which gives you an absolute measure of time. That said, clocks always measure relative time. This should not be surprising since it would be a very special clock indeed that had a reference to the big bang (presumably, a very sophisticated astrophysical measurement based on macroscopic properties of the universe like the microwave background radiation could be re-purposed to do this). There exists past, present and future. This is not just an artifact of consciousness as some would have you believe but a real property of the universe. One that physicists struggle with. But it is easily demonstrated in an intuitive way: what happens, with respect to time, when you impart some knowledge that only you know to someone else? Let us say that you received a phone call, you put the phone down and you turn to your brother and say “our mother is dead”. There is a definite past (mom is alive) there is the present (well that is the most interesting part of the question and there is the future (mom remains dead). Now, most of the other responses are based on magical thinking. In my terms, that would mean that somehow our Mother could be alive again and other completely wishful imaginings. But we should not confuse imagination—which is wonderful and magical and the source of all creativity—with reality where the past is the past. You cannot change it. You can certainly edit your view of the past, but I take this question to be a literal one. Credit where credit is due—Richard Muller is my source for the big bang idea. But I don’t have any idea how he would view this answer….so please don’t revile him if you disagree…

As crazy as it sounds, time is nothing more than an illusion created by our minds as we perceive changes in the state of the universe around us. Start by thinking about this thing we call the "moment", that point in time happening right now as you read this. It is an invisible barrier between what we envisage as the future and what recall as having already happened, the past. Exactly how long does the moment last? It can't be any particular measurable length of time, as no matter how impossibly small a unit you calculate, there is an infinite number of units smaller than that. The very moment you commenced measuring a moment, the moment has already passed. Is it nothingness then? An instant transformation between the future (which does not yet exist - it is something that has not yet happened) and the past (which also does not exist anymore, except in our memories). If so, then again this proves time does not exist - there is no future, no present and no past. It is an interesting thought. It means that what we think of as "now" is actually the exact same "now" that existed at the moment of the Big Bang, the moment life first evolved on the planet, the moment King Henry VIII was crowned, the moment the American Constitution was first written, etc. The moment never passes. It is always the same - this thing we call "the moment" or "now". This is not a new thought. Einstein concluded there is no such thing as “now” and is quoted as saying "....for us physicists believe the separation between past, present, and future is only an illusion, although a convincing one." (To ensure I do not quote Einstein out of context, it is important to point out that Einstein concluded that the past, the present and the future might exist simultaneously, a slightly different slant on the concept that time is just an illusion). So if time does not actually exist, why does everyone think it does? The perception of time arises because everything in the universe is constantly moving/changing. Day becomes night as the Earth rotates on its axis. We breathe. We eat. We age. Things around us move. Our perception of the changing state of the universe around us, gained through our continuous consciousness, gives us the sensation of the passage of time. This perception is influenced by external factors, such as the rotation of the earth. Right now you perceive it to be a very specific time of the day or night, but that is not reality. It is just perception. People all around the world are perceiving this very same "now" quite differently. Some think it is morning. Some are ready to each lunch, others are watching the sun set in the evening whilst some are fast asleep in the dead of night. All of them are experiencing "now" based purely on their perception. Our perception of time is not fixed either. It is a well documented fact that various substances can cause us to perceive time differently, even though there has been no change in the rate of changes taking place in the universe around us. Time appears to exist. However, time itself does not exist. If all this does your head in, don't worry. The possibility that time does not actually exist does not matter. We can still measure what we perceive as time. We have constructed devices to give us very precise measurements of "time". We can still predict what will happen in the future or schedule things for the future based on our perception of time. The past, although just memories or recorded information, still matters. Time can be used in calculations, to prove or disprove scientific theories and to help us run our lives, but as hard as it is to accept, it is really all just an illusion.

Thanks for the A2A. No, time does not exist in the universe. There are such things as change, rhythm, and process, but not time. All the forms we experience as change in and of themselves are energetic processes. There is no third party agent called time that, as it were, forces change upon what would otherwise be changeless objects. Time is a human social convention. It is a method of of synchronising our behaviour in terms of socially defined symbols, so that we may function harmoniously together in regular, predictable patterns. Time is perhaps best thought of as one of the fundamental game rules that are the basis of human community. By compromising our intuitive, spontaneous behaviour as physical organisms in order to function together according to a set of symbols, human beings are capable of highly sophisticated cooperative action that (most of the time) increases the survival chances of every individual involved. The important thing to remember about this process of pinning spontaneous behaviour to symbolic order, however, is that all these symbols are created by us, for us, and do not exist except to the degree that we give them power to dictate our collective behaviour. Now, you may respond to this, "But I literally perceive this thing called time. It's a physical experience. How can it be unreal?" This experience of the flow of time, progressing from the past into the future, is what we might call a conventional illusion. Now, I have to be very careful in explaining what I mean by an illusion, because this is a word that is bandied about quite a lot in fuzzy and unclear ways. An illusion is a process that appears a certain way to an observer, but upon closer scrutiny, it is seen that the appearance does not reflect the true nature of the process. Once this is seen, one's perception alters to take into account the true state of affairs. The classic example is a mirage in the desert. Our perception of time is this kind of phenomenon. When we were children, we were immersed in the many symbols and conventions that the society into which we were born uses to synchronise and dictate behaviour. The human brain is very impressionable, and we quickly learned to use thought and language to govern our behaviour. What happens is that when we start thinking in terms of the symbols given to us by our society, it's very difficult to stop, and so we are not aware of how the very act of thinking itself distorts our perception of the true state of affairs of the universe. In other words, very early on we are taken in by a kind of necessary social hypnosis, that, because we are too young question it, and it is so essential to cooperative behaviour, we rarely, if ever, become explicitly aware that it has happened. We think in terms of linear patterns of symbols. What happens is that, because the human brain has such a sophisticated reflective capacity, this constant stream of thought, combined with more sense-based memories, leave a trace upon our conscious mind in the same way that a ship leaves a wake in the water. As we think incessantly, and are constantly referring to our memories as we negotiate the world, we feel that the world flows past us in a linear way. What we don't ordinarily realise is that it is the linear patterns of thought and memories themselves that create this vivid experience of a linear flow, and that this experience is not actually an intrinsic aspect of direct perception. The perception of time feels very real indeed because the symbols in which we think are so fundamental to our lives that they have an acute impact upon our nervous system and sensory experience. The constant comparing and contrasting between memory and direct experience by means of symbols and images is the experience of the flow of time. This is almost the opposite of our ordinary common sense wherein we suppose that we use thought and memory to guide our trajectory through time, but in actual fact it is the act of thinking and referring to memory themselves that create the experience of time. The more sophisticated a civilisation becomes, that is, the more subtle our use of thought becomes to direct experience, the more deeply entrenched the illusion of time becomes. Time is so essential to socialised human behaviour today that it seems absurd to question its reality. This is why it is quite rare that an individual comes into the realisation that time is an hallucination maintained only by social consensus. Nothing is more compelling than social convention, because the use of thought and symbols to govern our collective behaviour is essentially the fabric of our lives. As modern human beings, we rely on these things for our survival almost as much as we rely upon oxygen to breath. It is not difficult to see, then, why we should be unconsciously so reluctant to see through the distortions of perception created by incessant thought. If anything could be analogous with extracting oneself from The Matrix in reality, it's that. But if time doesn't exist, what is the true nature of experience? The great difficulty in answering this question is that we are almost unable to conceive of an experience of the universe in which we are not using thought to govern our behaviour, in the same way that a fish cannot conceive of life within a medium other than water. Through practices such as meditation we can silence the thinking mind long enough to realise that we exist within an 'ever-changing now', wherein change occurs spontaneously and without any inherent linear progression. Everything simply unfolds within this now in the same way that a piece of music or a dance unfolds; unforced and not going anywhere in particular. In other words, change simply happens of itself, for itself, without any particular origin or destination. Such a state of affairs seems radically counter-intuitive, but only because we are so deeply conditioned into a way of experiencing wherein we view everything in terms of the linear patterns and agendas of thought. How can change simply happen for itself without explicit purpose or agenda? To this one can only say, "Stop thinking and see for yourself." For more on this topic, see my answers to How is time an illusion? and If we were to scientifically conclude that our perception of time is un-scientific and that all points in time exist simultaneously, what would the effects of such a conclusion be?

Time is and has always been referred to as a relative concept. Philosophy and physics may seem like polar opposites, but they regularly address quite similar questions. Recently, physicists have revisited a topic with modern philosophical origins dating over a century ago: the unreality of time. What if the passage of time were merely an illusion? Can a world without time make sense? While a world without the familiar passage of time may seem far-fetched, big names in physics, such as string theory pioneer Ed Witten and theorist Brian Greene, have recently embraced such an idea. A timeless reality may help reconcile differences between quantum mechanics and relativity, but how can we make sense of such a world? If physics does indeed suggest that the flow of time is illusory, then philosophy may be able to shed light on such a strange notion. McTaggart’s argument against the reality of time has a number of interpretations, but his argument starts with a distinction about ordering events in time. The “A” series and “B” series of time form an integral part of McTaggart’s argument, and I’ll unravel this distinction with an example historical event. On July 20, 1969, Apollo 11 became the first manned spacecraft to land on the moon. For argument’s sake, consider this event to represent an event during the present. Several days in the past (July 16), then, Apollo 11 lifted off the ground. Additionally, several days in the future all of the mission astronauts will land back on earth, safe and sound. Classifying an event as “several days past,” or “several days future,” falls under the “A” series. For the moon landing, some events (e.g. Lincoln’s assassination) are in the distant past; some events are in the distant future (e.g. the inauguration of President Obama); and other events fall somewhere in between. Under the “A” series, events flow from one classification (i.e. past, present and future) to another. On July 16th, the moon landing would have the property of being in the future. The instant the Apollo 11 landed on the moon, that event would be present. After this moment, its classification changes to the past. The “B” series, however, doesn’t classify events on this scale ranging from the distant past to the distant future. Instead, the “B” series orders events based on their relationship to other events. Under this ordering, Lincoln’s assassination occurs before the moon landing, and Obama’s inauguration occurs after the moon landing. This relational ordering seems to capture a different way of looking at time. If you would like more information please check out this website: The Unreality of Time Quantum Experiment Shows How “Time” Doesn’t Exist As We Think It Does (Mind-Altering) Hope I was of assistance.

Yes, time, just like consciousness, does exist from our perspective. You wrote a question in the past, now I’m answering your question in my present, and you’re (hopefully) reading my answer now (in your present and my future). Thus, this proves that time exists and you have consciousness. That said, there are still many things we probably don’t understand about time or consciousness. Certain things we may never know in this life. If you’re asking about time existing OUTSIDE of our plane of existence, that’s where things get interesting. It’s pretty easy to understand that one of the two scenarios probably exist outside/beyond our existence: A) Time does not exist. or B) Time is not governing. We know this because if “nothing” ever existed, then we would not be here, as it’s impossible for something to come from nothing. The fact that I (and you) have consciousness proves that we do exist. Therefore, beyond our existence, there was never a “beginning” and it can be further extrapolated that there will likely be ever be an “end”. At least something, possibly everything, always existed and will always exist. These ideas are very difficult to really wrap your mind around, as they are very incongruent with what we know in this existence. To come to the understanding that something always existed and never had a beginning is more mind-blowing to me than anything I have ever known. I feel like it’s a small peak behind the curtain. If you think about it, it’s possibly the only fact that could never really concealed about what’s beyond our plane of existence. Trippy.

Technically, no ... time does not exist.  What we've ever been measuring when we measure "time" is the motion of matter.  Motion by definition has a rate, since objects exist within 3-dimensional space and a changing of position inherently has a rate of change.  This rate of change is from where we've distilled the concept and the measurement of what we call "time", and it's seemingly a reliable measurement for what we use it for. However, consider our most reliable timekeeping device, the atomic clock.  Suppose we developed an advanced timekeeping device that achieved a measurement 1000 times more exact, that could report 1000 times more slices of time every second.  What we'd like to do with such a timekeeping device is use it to verify the quality of the atomic clock.  We want to see how well the atomic clock keeps rhythm and how consistent its counts are.  One tick of this new clock we'll call a "pixie".  So we use this new clock to measure how many pixies there are per atomic-clock tick.  And predictably we find that it varies slightly and occasionally wildly, how many pixies go by in between each atomic tick. How can we determine what's going on with our atomic clock??  The answer is...  we can't.  Not only is it impossible to determine which clock it is that's varying to cause the inconsistencies, but some of the environmental effects that are causing the inconsistency could be affecting BOTH clocks simultaneously.   The inherent difficulty here is that timekeeping devices are a PHYSICAL standard.  They measure the motion of matter which is susceptible to skew from a huge assortment of physical forces. Time doesn't exist, only matter exists...  and matter can be in motion.

Time is a dimension much like space. So if time is an illusion, so is space. Also, time corresponds to energy, and space to momentum. Which would mean that energy and momentum are also not real. That seems unlikely to me, so I think that time is real. The so-called arrow of time is a different matter. There are three arrows of time:  The thermodynamic arrow (entropy increases)The psychological arrow (we remember the past but not the future)The cosmological arrow (the universe always gets bigger)The thermodynamic arrow is statistical, because there are more ways for entropy to be higher than lower. So if there's a change, it's far more likely that it's going to a state with more possibilities than fewer. In terms of heat, which was what it was originally about, heat flows from hot to cold. Put an ice cube in a glass of hot water, and you get a glass of lukewarm water later, not the other way around. The psychological arrow is because our brains are Shannon information processing systems, as are computers. The brain gets hot and then cools off. That's thermodynamic, too.  The cosmological arrow is that the universe always gets bigger. That may be the same things as well. It seems to me that a smaller universe has fewer states, and there's less range for entropy. Start off like that, and the only way to go is up.  There's a bit more funniness. If you look at Maxwell's equations, they should work just as well backward as forward. So why can't we hear tomorrow's radio broadcasts? The best idea seems to be that they do go back in time, but they always hit something that reflects a signal forward in time that completely cancels it out. Pretty cool. That would only work if the universe was smaller, down to a point, so there's always something to hit and reflect forward. You can't pick up the broadcasts because the reflection and cancellation has already happened. If the universe is always getting bigger, eventually, there's nothing to hit, so there's no reflected signal coming back in time to cancel it out. That's a pretty cool idea, too. Whether it's an accurate model is another thing.

I guess you mean does time have a tangible nature? Because if it doesn't, and its an abstract, then it exists only in our mind. Well, if time is a tangible thing, there would be evidence of its existence. You cant touch it, see it, hear it or smell it. There is NO evidence of it causing anything (don't make the mistake of confusing time measuring something with time causing something). All outcomes are the result of energy differential...time isn't an energy (at least there is no evidence of it being so). Time doesn't 'do' anything. ALL WE EVIDENCE ARE EVENTS HAPPENING.  Zillions and zillions of quantum events. That's not evidence of (tangible) time; this is merely evidence of events. So, if there is NO evidence of times tangible existence, we must start with the premise that it is abstract - i.e. time is just a word that we have attached meanings to (as opposed to a 'thing' that we have attached a name/word to such as a door or gravity). IF time is just a word, then its meaning is simply that which we (the originators of the word) choose to attach.Then if you look in a dictionary there appears to be many uses of the word time. BUT if you break those many varied uses down they split into two separate distinct though similar CORE definitions:-1 Time is the abstract framework (mental model) that we use to measure, calibrate and reference events. It is the T as used in mathematics and science. 2. Time is a non-specific set of events  - for example when we say "time passes" what we are really evidencing are events happening (there is nothing more we evidence). This dual definition of time is comprehensive for all uses of the word. [It therefore demands that space-time be recognised as an abstract reference framework too - you can't mix two paradigms of incompatible nature]. Time then is merely a word that allows us to frame events (and to calibrate intervals) either in a mathematical framework, or as a collective expression. So in answer to your question, yes, time exist, but only in our minds. The underlying fundamental (tangible) to which it refers are events.

What time is ? We have divided time into past, present and future. But if we closely observe our own life we will be surprised to know that we almost alway live in the past bypassing the present. The time called present is a very very thin line in between the past and the future and it moves in so tremendous a speed that, it is very difficult to stand on its first moving current. Before going to different parts of time, let us first try to understand what is time. What is time ? Is it a truth ? Is there really anything called time? There is of course space and there is continuous movement and change in it. There is also a birth or beginning of space , as science says, so there must be an end of it. There is beginning and end of things, birth and death of life. From this beginning and end , the concept of time is born, otherwise there is nothing called time. Time is , therefore , a concept of human mind to measure the rate of change of things, of life. Change is continuous and happening at this very moment which is called the present. So there is only one state of time, the present. Present is the only truth of time. There is nothing called past or future of time. Past and future are nothing but the expansion of time by the human mind. What we call past is just a heap of memories, an accumulation of memories lived or experienced by our senses in the time present, the reality of life. The present, the reality of life is moving or changing in such a tremendous speed , that we are not sensitive enough or our sense organs are not strong enough to live the present, live the realities of life always, each and every moment. So the mind collects and stores them as memories to live them again and again at leisure. These memories are lived or recurred as thoughts. To summarise, past is just a bunch of memories and thoughts, a reality that has already become a thing of the past, a dead thing, a death. And it is a paradox and also a matter of great surprise that all lower animals live in the present, live there realities sensitively but man having all abilities and sensibilities to live the realities of life live almost always in the past, in thoughts, in memories. Man lives not life but lives death. This is indeed a serious problem of human life and it is of utmost necessity to explore the cause and remedy of it. Though we call the past time Bhoota kala , not in the sense of ghost or apparition but surprisingly it seems nothing more than an apparition which has already been turned into a ghost riding on our shoulders. To get rid of that ghost, let us then explore how memory is formed to create the concept of the past. The realities that we live through our sense organs, create sensations of pain and pleasure on our body and the moment we react to them they turn into memories and are stored in our mind. We generally react in the form of desire s, that we desire pleasure and desire not pain. The more strong is the reaction or desire , the more deep and long lasting is the memory. So it is the desire that is responsible for the formation of Bhoota , the past. If there would have been no desire , there would have been no memory. If at all it would have then it would have been not so deep and strong to turn into a ghost to occupy and acquire our mind. Is it possible then to remain neutral and unaffected to whatever happens at the present , to the sensation of both pain and pleasure? Can we live life just as an audience not as an actor , just as a witness , as a drasta not as a bhokta ? Then only perhaps , we will be able to live the reality sensitively from moment to moment and there will be no bondage of the past, the ghost . Let us then try to know how to overcome the pressure of memories and impressions which creates division of time. Earlier we have seen that there is nothing called past and future of time. It is a creation of the mind out of its stored memories. If at all there is a state of time then it is only the present. The present is reality, is freedom. But because we do not live most of the time here and now , which is the present and caught by past memories that weighs on us making life a false movement. To overcome it's pressure , we must first know what memory is and how it is formed. Out of depisited memories a hard disc of Sanskar takes form. What is Sanskara ? In a life time whatever action is done, remains deposited in the genes of the cell as impressions and in the mental field as memories. The deposits of memories in the mental field take the form of Sanskara. In fact, all those actions that put a deep scar in the mind remain as Sanskara till the last moment of death, which acts as a seed for the next birth. After death, though the genes get destroyed with the decomposition of the body, there is no possibility of destruction of the Sanskara, being a very subtle world of feelings. What we call mind, is actually a state of consciousness in the body, where the deposits of memories take the form of mind. The destruction of the memories deposited in the consciousness become impossible with the death of the body, as they are the impression of subtle feelings very close to the nature of consciousness. To overcom the pressure of memorie or to be free from suffering, is therefore to be free from Sanskara and to be free from sanskara is needed change of the old habit pattern of the mind, which are churning of thoughts, instability, fickleness and netting of hopes and desires. What actually is the cause of the old habit of the mind? When the external world enters into the body through the sense organs, a wave of sensation runs throughout the body. When mind reacts to the sensation, which is basically of either pleasure or pain, gets automatically stored as memories in the mind. The deposits in due course take the form of Sanskara. Because of ignorance, though we search and see the cause of pain and pleasure in the outside world, yet, the cause lies in the reaction of the inner mind to the sensations of pain and pleasure created in the body. If the mind, without being attracted to the sensation of pleasure and repelled by that of pain, remains just a seer of those sensations, then there is no possibility of birth of Bikara (mental dirt) or Sanskara. It means, the mind which was so far an enjoyer of pleasant and unpleasant sensations, has to give up its old natural habits and remain as an unaffected seer. And it is possible only when mind is able to see truth of it, that the sensation of pain and pleasure is impermanent. To see the truth, the mind must first be calm, quiet, alert, and aware. We know a lot of the external world of living and non-living, but are ignorant of our own inner world, our body and mind. Though, we have some control over sense activities, but no knowledge and control over the activities, such as blood circulation, digestive system, respiratory system and nervous system. We can have a gross idea about the anatomy of the body by reading books, but it is impossible to know the action and reaction, movement and vibration, birth, decay and death taking place inside innumerable cells and innumerable atoms in the cells of the body. Also we are ignorant of the nature of the mind, the reality and activity of its subconscious and unconscious state. The activities on the surface mind are nothing but the reflection of the activities taking place in the inner mind. That is why, in spite of all efforts to keep the surface mind calm, quiet and pure through rituals and intellectual discourse, the deposited Sanskara of desire, anger, greed and lust in the subconscious mind come up like water bubbles through loopholes to make the surface mind polluted and unstable. It is therefore necessary to make whole sphere of mind pure and free from Sanskara. Let us now know, how Sanskara is made and grows with the interaction of the body and mind. The five senses, the eyes, nose, ears, tongue and the skin are the means for the formation of Sanskara and form, smell, sound, taste and feeling of touch of the external world are the subjects related to them. But the real creator of Sanskara is the mind. So long the mind is not conscious and active, senses do not bring any result. After the senses come in contact with their related subjects a wave of sensation is created throughout the body. Then a part of the mind becomes aware of the sensation, which is its cognitive activity. Another part of the mind then, investigates about the sense related objects and with the help of the memories stored earlier, recognises their state of realties and evaluates the nature of sensation created in the body. When the sensations are evaluated as either pain or pleasure, they become stronger to force another part of mind to react. The reactions manifested are in the form of craving towards pleasure and aversion towards pain, which are again deposited as memories in the mind. Through the process of cognition, recognition, action and reaction the Sanskara thus is made in and by the inner mind beyond the knowledge of the surface conscious mind. Desire is born out of craving for pleasure and aversion for pain. Mind always desires for pleasure and not for pain. The source of pleasure and pain are in the outside world which are in a flux as per the law of nature and therefore are impermanent. Along with the body and mind, the whole material world is changeable and impermanent. But mind desires pleasure to be permanent which is not possible. Therefore suffering becomes inevitable. Suffering as such is the truth of life. But because the desire for pleasure gives birth to suffering, it becomes an unending chain in which life becomes entangled. The ignorance of the mind of the truth of impermanence is the root cause of suffering.

Time does exist. If you understand the basic concepts of Special Relativity, you understand Time Dilation. If time did not really exist, it would have absolutely no deviations from its natural state of going in just one direction and not being dependent upon anything. If that were true we could hypothesize that time is just a man made construct which aids our understanding of various theories but in truth, there is only the present time, since we have no proof that time is not a “constant” phenomenon, in other words, it does not really exist (or need to exist) since it only behaves in one way with absolutely no change. It is just something that we tend to experience (since our brain stores memories and always tries to predict the future). But Time Dilation has shown that all of this is not true. That time and space are very much dependent upon the observer. Both space and time work together on this (one affects the other), which is why we use the word “spacetime”. With so many experiments and applications of Special and General Relativity, we know that the theories are correct (it could be that they need to be extended or improved upon, but certainly, they have shown that time does change and vary with different observers). If you go near a blackhole (see: Interstellar), time for you moves very very very slowly compared to, say, the Earth. One hour near the blackhole could be 7 years on Earth! This change in experience of time because of being under influence (of the gravity of the blackhole) shows how time can be affected by gravity and hence begs us to believe that Time is real! It does exist!

Time does not exist. Only the illusion of time exists within a conscious observer (ie a time keeper).  To the conscious observer change of position within space creates the illusion of time. To model this, time is a function of a conscious observer, something moving, energy acting on this something moving and space for this something to move from one position to another position. Time is always the dependent variable. These factors create the illusion or perception of time. If time was real and moved, it would require or even would create energy, it does neither. Unfortunately, our society's need and desire to over simplify processes commonly leads to time's misuse as a independent variable (i.e. x/bottom axis in graphs). This misrepresentation of time acting to "cause" phenomenon is taught and reinforced in our society almost everywhere. We are taught that time causes action. Time "causes" the recycling bin to overflow that needs to be taken out on Wednesday, my children to move to the next grade in school and us to get old. However, time causes nothing to happen, it is the byproduct of observable action. Of course, that does not negate the practical fact that the recycling goes out on Wednesday. One comes to this question, "Does time exist?", perhaps in search of the fundamentals to their own existence. When I think about my life and it's "obvious" beginning and end, time becomes the perceived vehicle of my demise. If I intelligently deny time's existence then I also, in a way, deny my own possibility of non-existence (though subconsciously).   While physics is commonly used to define time or defend its existence or not, this topic is more personal, psychological and philosophical than physical. Time is constructed by the conscious observer (you) and thus it's existence or illusion of existence is only relevant to the you.

There's no doubt whatsoever about the existence of time. If we didn’t have it, we wouldn’t have causality, and if we didn’t have causality, it would be next to impossible to just coincidentally have this extreme complexity around us, emerging out of nowhere. It is because we do have causality inside this time dimension, which made it possible to start with this nearly perfectly homogeneous, dense, expanding quark plasma, right after the Big Bang, which had both very low entropy (a measure of disorder) and very low complexity, to be causally interacting to slowly change this soup into the high complexity, medium entropy as we find our universe today, ultimately ending with low complexity again, but maximum entropy: the heat death of the universe. It’s analogous to the change inside a glass of milk and coffee;  Entropy continually increases, but the most complexity is right in the middle.  It is this continuous increase of entropy towards one direction of time that is completely responsible for what we call ‘time’ in our day-to-day lives. Think of entropy as the measure of disorder of a system, referring to the number of microscopic states it can be in. For instance, when we shoot pool, and hit the orderly cluster of billiard balls inside the triangle, entropy will be most likely to increase. But if all those balls somehow happen move in the exact opposite direction and speed, after our first shot, they would actually meet again in the lower entropy triangle shape.  According to physics there is nothing that says that the reverse situation is an impossible situation, but it is just highly unlikely. Imagine then how incredibly unlikely this must be for the particles that makes up our Universe! When we look at a video recording that’s played back in reverse, all the things that look strange to us there, are phenomena that simply show an unnatural decrease in entropy. All the strange phenomena in reverse are explained by it. All of it. Balls starting motionless and suddenly bumping higher and higher, because the chaotic motion of molecules (heat) from the floor are suddenly ‘tunneled’ in unison at just the right moment into one single direction into the ball. Luke warm water in a bathtub, changing to hot water on one side, and cold water on the other side. Shaking a box with black and white balls, resulting in neatly separated black balls on the left and white on the right. Infants solving Rubik’s cubes. Eggs un-frying. Etc., etc…. Even though all these unnaturally entropy-increasing phenomena are technically physically possible to occur like that in real life, it is just ridiculously unlikely, similar to the (much likelier) situation of billiard balls meeting up into an orderly triangle shape. But if we’d actually zoom in to only a few particles within any of these weird entropy reversed examples, it now actually looks perfectly normal. Every single interaction between just a few particles always looks perfectly natural, played either forward in time or backward in time, just like any collision between two billiard balls always looks perfectly normal when played either backward or forward. It all has to do with there being more possibilities for the system at large to go into an increase in entropy, than a decrease in entropy. All laws of physics work the same way forward in time as they do backwards, except for this statistical law, known as the second law of thermodynamics. The only reason for why there are so many more possibilities for an increase in disorder, why we always see entropy increasing, and why we experience this direction of time, is because at one side of the time dimension there somehow was this extremely low state of entropy, right after what we call the Big Bang. With a Big Bang at the “other side” of the time dimension, we’d simply experience time flowing away from that direction of low entropy, but our current particles would then look like their CP reversed anti-particles. Maybe all of time before the Big Bang has entropy increasing towards the other direction, and is that the side where all our missing anti-particles went. Time seeming to have a fundamental direction is somewhat analogous to space seeming to have a direction for us as well, being near a source of gravity.  The reason it is so much easier for us to know the details of the past, and not the details of the future, is because it ends up being more precise and easier to calculate towards the lower entropy direction, even when only processing just a fragment of the information provided, like for instance a small part of the light reflected by a surface. The higher entropy direction of time on the other hand is much less precise to calculate to, especially when handling only a fragment of information. With just a small calculation error, the difference might escalate to set other things in motion that wasn’t taken into account, even ignoring the probabilistic nature of our reality. If just one billiard ball happens to hit some other orderly triangle of billiard balls on the table, we see a completely different situation at the future side of time. But calculating the other way around is much easier. We just have to look at a broken egg on the ground, and we immediately know that was an unbroken egg before. But when we look at an unbroken egg, we don’t know if it’s gonna fall, gets eaten, or ends up rotting away somewhere: there’s just too many branches for which we need more detailed information to calculate. Of course, our brains calculate both the future and the past side, it’s just that one side is a lot clearer than the other, even though we lose a lot of details of history as well, the further we go. But we lose the details of the future side much faster. As long as we are alive, our evolved bodies are fighting against increasing entropy where it’s unwanted, by consuming low-entropy energy sources, and excreting back what we've eaten in a higher-entropy form. It’s not enough to just receive energy, we need free energy: F≡U−TS, where F is free energy, U is regular energy, T is the temperature, and S is the entropy. Note that the term TS comes with a negative sign. For instance, the sea has a lot of heat energy, but it’s by no means free energy. We get a lot of free, low-entropy energy in the form of short-wavelength radiation from the Sun, which then largely re-radiates back into space. The difference? Earth's radiation goes out as long-wavelength light with added entropy:  Our own bodies consume low-entropy energy from food and emit high-entropy long-wavelength radiation back, and tries to keep itself in a low entropy state, by continuous repairing and avoiding, as long as we’re alive. The information in our brains, on the other hand, depends a lot on the natural mechanism of increasing entropy. Just think of a nice, orderly packet of data in the form of photons, entering our eyes and hitting our retinas, which sets off this collision course of interpretations inside our brains. Again, the reverse is also technically possible, but extremely improbable: our brains setting off signals to our eyes, shooting off photons from our retinas.

Take two pendulums of different lengths. You will find that their oscillations don’t coincide. We can take some oscillations from a quartz crystal and we an quantify the difference in the period of oscilation of the two pendulums in a number of quartz oscillations. So we have a quantity that can be measured and, by convention, we call this quantity time. Its units should be a certain number of cycles that we deem to be stable. In fact the unit of time (the second) is defined as follows: “The second is the duration of 9 192 631 770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the cesium 133 atom.” But, in practice, we find the second, just like the metre is variable according to the relative velocity and acceleration (or gravitational field strength) of the observer. So time exists in the same sense as space exists, not as an object, but as a measurement system and which, together with space, differentiates events. But “spacetime” exists in another sense: It is the “metric” or “field” which is deformed around a mass which gives rise to these differences in our measurements of space and time. We are used to the idea of an electricomagnetic field being deformed by the presence of a charge, a magnet or a current. We can also think of a four-dimensional field called ”spacetime” distorted by the presence of mass which affects our measurements of time and distance. To sum up, time exists as a measurement system of a number of cycles, and spacetime exists as a field which can distort these measurements.

Entropy exists - and as a consequence, so must time. The second law of thermodynamics essentially states that the entropy of the universe is always increasing, and it never decreases. Not even if the entropy is pulled into a black hole - which one would think may be a good way of removing it. It is this knowledge of entropy that allows us to determine the direction in time that any given particle or object is moving. Thus, there is a direction. And there is movement, or magnitude of difference between one moment and the next. Sounds like we have a vector - a mathematical object with a magnitude and direction. From what little I know about it: time is considered to be a scalar quantity (and not a vector). It is said to be a scalar because it lacks “directional” quality. But entropy irrevocably binds a direction to time. Thus there may more than one way to consider time: we could remove entropy from the measurement and hold it to be a scalar quantity - or we could include entropy in the dimension of time - whereby it would seem to take on a direction, and thus, become a vector quantity. Perhaps this would be known as entropic time, or absolute time? Then again, absolute time would not be the best name, as absolute value removes directionality and reduces vector quantities to scalar quantities. Something to think about… and then again, I expect relativity theory would shred my idea of absolute time as being completely blockheaded. But we still must account for the increase in entropy providing for direction to events that occur in the universe. This does seem to impart some kind of absoluteness to the mix. Regardless of absolute time or not - the quantity of entropy - and it is a real quantity (measured in Joules or Watts per Kelvin) - makes time an imperative phenomenon in the universe. If time were not real - then violation of the 2nd Law of Thermodynamics would be possible. But at this moment in time - we know of no phenomenon capable of violating this law, and as such, time must exist as a correlation to this law.

A2A: From my rather simple (minded?) understanding this seems to be a pretty complex and challenging topic. On one hand it is very clear that time does exist in the form of the measuring system we use to order and understand sequences of events. Just as fathoms, pounds, and liters don’t occur naturally but help us understand the physical properties of nature so do months, minutes, and milliseconds help us understand the temporal ones. Where it gets complicated is sorting out what exactly it is we are measuring and it's fundamental relationships to reality. It strikes me as somewhat similar to our understanding of gravity. We have the means to very precisely measure, model, and predict the effects of gravity but as far as I know it is still unclear as to what it is. I think it's safe to say that what we perceive as the passage of time is a property of the reality we observe. Whether this reality is some infinite realm of all possible outcomes through which we are charging one particular course, or if our course is the only one there is, or some other multiverse or similar model, or something we can't even imagine seems to me difficult or impossible to discern at the present time. Much has been written about this by people far more expert than I so I will leave it at that rather than embarrass myself with further rambling.

In a spatially 3-D universe, it certainly appears so, although many things, such as delayed choice experiments and Bell’s inequality and more strongly hint that Time may be, as a property of the universe, far less fundamental than it seems. Moreover, a simple mind game predicated on well-known physics shows that indeed, Time as we perceive it has got to be an illusion. Here goes: Simple relativistic mathematics—the Lorentz transformation—shows that time, speed, and distance do not exist independently of one another but are inextricably entangled. The way this interdependence works out in the real world is counter-intuitive: stay put and look towards some star light years away. You happen to be, as you contemplate deep space towards that star from your fixed position, simultaneous with some event A on it. But now walk towards it: you have now become simultaneous with some other event B on that star, that happened (depending on your walking speed and the distance to the particular star) hours or even days earlier than the event A you were simultaneous with mere seconds ago when you were standing still. Now turn on your heels and walk away from the star: you have now become simultaneous with yet another event C, which took place hours or days later than A, and twice as long later than B. So far so good, it's simple math. But what happens if you start spinning, dervish-like, around your body axis? Then the right half of your brains becomes instantly and continuously simultaneous with events on that distant star that are separate by hours or days from the events your brain's left side is simultaneous with, although both your brain halves are closely, if not perfectly, simultaneous with each other. The whole concept of time has irremediably broken down. My 2015 monograph [The Far Horizons of Time] analyzed the issue and concluded that the only possible way out of the conundrum is that Time is not a fundamental variable of a mathematical universe, but a side effect of something more fundamental. That more essential something turned out to have to be, in some form or other, mindstuff. (Note that this analysis only shows that mindstuff has to be a more fundamental property of the universe than time, not that there may not exist something else, deeper still than mindstuff.)

In my opinion, time on its own doesn’t exist, but it is possible to artificially define time. What is certain to exist is radiation and matter. With radiation alone it is clear that it is not possible to define either time or space. Trap radiation between two mirrors or in going round in circles and you have rest energy, and with it comes rest-mass and gravitation. And by counting the number of such rotations/oscillations, a trapped radiation makes, we get time- we have here a local clock. Also consider that if you look at an empty patch of the sky, you can’t find how deep it is- that is unless you find something material there, then you can send light and get it back(at least in principle), count the number of rounds of the local clock and we can tell distance. So we see that both time and space are created with the creation of mass, which we couldn’t tell of their existence before. Nothing in the universe is static, and the smaller you go the higher the speed is- till hitting the limit of c at about the size of the electron. Motion involves changes in space and time together. Thus we see that in fact, it is space-time that was created with matter- which was already there when we had radiation, but we could not tell anything about it. On creating mass however, it is possible then to associate distance with linear motion and time with circular motion. Another way to separate space and time (artificially again) is by infinite averaging. Averaging over space gives us time, and averaging over time gives us space. The reason for saying ‘artificial’, is that to find distance we needed time as in sending the light beam example above.

I think that time must exist in some form, because we experience it. Disregarding the various creation myths, I assume that this universe was not intentionally designed by an intelligent being. Rather our universe is just one out of countless others, and by chance only, ours supports intelligent life such as humans. With that said, our universe was never designed with any grand purpose in mind. And it wasn’t designed so that we would have the “gift” of consciousness, or the gift of perceiving the passage of time. Our universe has no plan, because nobody is behind the wheel. There is no reason why our consciousness would be necessary in order for this universe to function. And yet we do perceive the passage of time. Why would that be the case if time wasn’t even a piece of the universe? Also, time seems to flow in one direction only.
