Because human beings perceive events as not happening all at once, but as preceding or following one another. Hence, the perception that what exists possesses the quality of proceeding in some existential direction. From that, humans refer to those events that are perceived to have already occurred as “past” events, those that are occurring contemporaneously as “present” events, and those that have not happened in the “past” or the “present” as “future” events. From this, it is easy for humans to begin measuring, and, in turn, to see all things as existing in a measured sequence we call “time.” One of the interesting aspects of “time” is that it is perceived as one-directional, while all other movements can be reversed. In time, we can only move from “past” to “present” to “future.” Of course we are well aware of this, and we entertain ourselves with imaginative scenarios about manipulating time. Where things begin to be fun is when we think of “time” as inextricably connected to “space.” Quantum physics, when it deals with entanglement, raises interesting questions about space-time.

Time? Hold my pint... There are actually four distinct KINDS of time: Societal, Scientific, Cerebral and Pure. Let us examine them… Societal Time is the one everybody is familiar with; it drives our lives. The average working stiff wakes at a time, leaves home at a time, gets a bus and/or train at a time, arrives at work at a time, has lunch from a time to a time – then leaves work at a time, gets another bus and/or train at a time and returns home at a time, to find his wife waiting with a martini or beer and if he is really lucky, wearing a baby-doll nightie and a come-hither grin – also at a time. This is the COMMERCIAL world – everything working to a CLOCK. Then there is Science, where everything works in SECONDS. Like, one Watt is one Joule per Second. You do not NEED minutes, hours, days, weeks, months, years, centuries or even millennia, because you have kilo-, mega-, giga-, terra-, peta-, exa-, zetta- and yotta-seconds. And one yotta-second – one times ten to the power twenty-four – a one with twenty-four zeros after it – a million-million-million-million – is over thirty thousand million, million years. And going SMALL, you have milli-, micro-, nano-, pico-, femto-, atto-, zepto- and yocto-seconds. And one yocto-second – one times ten to the power MINUS twenty-four – one OVER a one with twenty-four zeros after it – a million-million-million-millionTH – is the amount of time between a traffic light in front of you turning green – and some yahoo behind you yelling, “Oi mate, what shade of green are you waiting for?” But thus far, all time is governed by that damned clock. However as a retired person, Cerebral Time governs MY life. It means that I look at my tasks for the day and estimate how long they will take, whether I need daylight to do them, whether I can be arsed and so on – based on several decades of previous experience. And minutes and seconds are replaced by the abstract – time becomes SPACE. A high IQ helps here, since it confers on the victim the ability of spacial awareness. As for television, both retirees AND workers have had the convenience of VCRs for over thirty-five years and hard-drives for more than ten. So only a DUMMY watches the medium at the whim of TV schedulers (I have rarely watched television LIVE since 1981). Which brings us – and not a moment too soon – to PURE Time. First, a few words about Time TRAVEL. This is perceived to be the ability to travel PHYSICALLY backwards and forwards through the medium and is utter BOLLOCKS. We ALL travel forward in time when we sleep. And if the scientists ever perfect Cryogenic Stasis, those hours could become centuries. However, we are/would be hibernating. The world will grind on remorselessly without us. The real trick is travelling BACK in time – but there is a PROBLEM. “The past is another country; they do things differently there” is a misquote (it is actually “a foreign country”) from a book written in 1953, when few travelled abroad – but in terms of Time Travel it might as well be an ALIEN planet, since we will NEVER get there. Aside from the many tortuous paradoxes involved (don’t even get me started) we KNOW that Time Travel cannot and NEVER WILL be achieved, because if it were, events like Woodstock, the Kennedy Assassination and “9/11” would be inundated with future Time Travellers. And the many photos, films and videos taken at Max Yasgur’s farm, Dealey Plaza and the upwind rooftops of Manhattan on the relevant days clearly show all the people involved were contemporaneous. Period clothing would never disguise the inappropriate expressions the Travellers would inevitably be wearing. The reason Time Travel is impossible is because like the future, the past DOES NOT EXIST. There is only NOW. The concepts of Time we are all familiar with are Man-Made Constructs. What we call The Past is merely a record of previous Nows – and The Future, just a prediction of Nows to come. Neither can be reached, because RIGHT now – both are absent. And they always will be. Thus we can say, unequivocally, that PURE Time is merely two words which together – mean NOTHING. Sorry.

I know of three definitions: Subjective time, what we feel when we observe a change in the position of an object or a change in the state of energy of an object (it got hotter or cooler, for example) Objective time, when we measure the rate of those changes and compare to a standard unit of measure Relative time, when those measures occur in two different frames of reference that are moving in relation to each other. This last one gets a bit tricky, as I understand it (could be wrong) mass will accelerate or decelerate depending on the motion of its frame of reference but EM radiation (photons) do not, they have a constant velocity (represented as C in the famous equation E=MC^2) but the curvature of their trajectory can increase and decrease (frequency too) when they enter the deeper curvature around massive bodies. That’s known as general relativity. Then there is the notion of Absolute Time (or universal time) but that appears to be word play, nothing useful for us, because the 1st law of TD: energy cannot be created, so although the forms of energy have a history and a future, energy itself is timeless (perhaps you read the position that time is imaginary, that all existence exists in the one and only moment there really is, which is right NOW, but everything moves and we notice that movement so we feel that time is a real “thing”, etc. etc.) ergo no “absolute” time. So, to ask does time exist, the word refers to both the feeling we feel when we observe changes and when we measure the rates of change, etc.

Time is a concept based on the predictability of relative motion.  It began when man first recognized the recurring patterns of the motion in the stars, the moon, day and night and so on.  We broke it down into increasingly smaller increments as our need to remember, record and plan increased.  As our skills improved the demand for better planning increased.  So too, the need for improved technology in time keeping. For most of this human era our concept of time has been adequate, primarily because we were pretty well stuck to a small area on Earth.  This is rapidly changing.  We are moving faster, leaving our planet and soon the solar system.  We explore deep space.  Our abilities to plan are challenged more than ever.  Physicists examine our world in more ways looking for better answers to deal with managing our expansion.  Physics, the behavior of matter, has until recently been predictable.  Now we pursue the mysteries of quantum physics where predicability is troubling and probabilities difficult to ascertain.  Our concept of time needs to reevaluated as well.  Imagine trying to deal with things that may only probably have been or will hopefully be.  Check again in a few years ago.

Do I think time really exists? Hmmm, the question, as I understand it, is incomplete, although I would not have thought so just a couple of years ago. But then I saw a video where Neil Degrasse Tyson was explaining the space/time continuum, which for some reason I had never really grasped, and didn’t even realize it. I stubbornly persisted in thinking that space and time were separate, but they are not. They are irrevocably intertwined and where one is concerned, so must be the other. So the question might be more complete in this form: Do I think the space/time continuum exists? The way he explained it, so that even my simple mind could understand was this; if I say to you, let’s meet tomorrow at three o’clock, what would be your next utterance? Yes, of course, you would ask me, where? And if I said let’s meet tomorrow at the golf course, your next word would be, when? It is space/time, not space and time. Does it exist? It certainly does, in my humble opinion, because it works. If we agree to meet at a certain place at a certain time, and we are both dependable, then said meeting will occur. If it wasn’t real, I don’t think that would be the case. It’s real enough for me, at least. It’s like when I consider the question about is life really just an illusion? If it is, as long as it is so real that I cannot tell that it is an illusion, it might as well be real, and new evidence to the contrary notwithstanding, I will continue to assume it is real, and act accordingly. It’s worked so far, and that’s all that really matters. If it is all an illusion, none of us can tell, so what difference does it make? We are temporal creatures, we experience the passage of time, and indeed, it is hard to imagine existence without it. So yes, I think it exists.

We humans are hopelessly caught up in time. We experience the world sequentially: yesterday, then today, then tomorrow. The way that we are made makes us experience things this way and see the world the way we do.  But reality isn’t at all like we think. Modern physics tells us that time isn’t infinite (it started at the Big Bang, and may well end) and can move faster, slower and even in reverse. If this shatters your world-view, get over it. The best objective view of time I’ve encountered was penned by Boethius 1500 years before relativity, quantum mechanics or the Big Bang:  Eternity is the simultaneous and complete possession of infinite life. This will appear more clearly if we compare it with temporal things. All that lives under the conditions of time moves through the present from the past to the future; there is nothing set in time which can at one moment grasp the whole space of its lifetime. It cannot yet comprehend to-morrow; yesterday it has already lost. And in this life of today your life is no more than a changing, passing moment. … For though [the whole universe] apprehends and grasps a space of infinite lifetime, it does not embrace the whole simultaneously; it has not yet experienced the future. What we should rightly call eternal is that which grasps and possesses wholly and simultaneously the fullness of unending life, which lacks naught of the future, and has lost naught of the fleeting past. (Boethius, Consolation, pp. 68–69) Another allegory that I find useful is that of a tapestry.  The horizontal dimension is time and the vertical is space.Every person's life is a thread with a start-point, an end-point and a finite length. We can only see the threads we touch: threads that are in the same horizontal location (time) and close vertically (space).But the tapestry’s weaver, looking at the whole, sees the entire length of our thread, as well as all threads to our left and right, above and below.The best objective view of time is that events depicted in the tapestry don’t happen at all, they simply are.

The concept of time can be approached from several angles. For physicists, it is primarily a mathematical concept that can take on different values depending on the frame of reference and is in principle (at the level of quanta) reversible, and duration is simply the numerical order of changes in space. For Swiss clock makers it is something that can be measured by constructing more and more refined (and expensive) watches, from a thermodynamic point of view the second law can be seen as the arrow of time (nobody has so far defeated Maxwell’s daemon), for humans time can be experienced differently, where it can pass subjectively more slowly or quickly or-momentarily- stand still. Our bodies have many oscillating systems which could be described as ‘time keepers’ the most salient being our metabolic rate: when it speeds up time slows down subjectively, if it slows down it passes more quickly. So, sitting on a hot stove which will increase your metabolic rate, a minute might seem like five minutes. Night and day (and the moon too) signals to us, along with all other animals, the temporal rhythms which govern life. Also, emotions can influence our perception of time: http://ttps://www.psychologicalscience.org/observer/the-fluidity-of-time The only meaning the concept of time has for us is in relation to our experience and understanding of the world. Here I think nobody has, so far, improved on Kant’s proposal that time and space are the two fundamental cognitive categories into which we order our experiences. They are not to be thought of as having an existence independently of us, but as the basic principles through which we construct the phenomenal appearance of the world. It is they that impose the way we perceive the world. From this it follows that time exists as a concept which we are compelled to use to project onto the flow of experience a temporal order, because the category is a ‘build-in’ feature of our cognitive (even physiological) apparatus. Here a poetic take on it by Johann Gottfried von Herder, 1744-1803, a contemporary of Kant (those two knew about each other), and my attempt at translating it. Ein Traum, ein Traum ist unser Leben  Auf Erden hier. Wie Schatten auf den Wogen schweben  Und schwinden wir Und messen unsre trägen Tritte  Nach Raum und Zeit; Und sind (und wissen's nicht) in Mitte  Der Ewigkeit. A dream, a dream is our life On earthen here. Like shadows on waves we hover And we disappear And measure our leaden steps In space and time; And are (unknowingly) at the centre Of eternity.

What time is remains a mystery. General Relativity ended the notion of time as being separate from space such that rather than discrete time and discrete space, we have spacetime. Hawkins proposed that at the earliest stages of the universe, time was actually a 4th spatial dimension that, over time (whatever that is), became a temporal dimension leaving us with only 3 spatial dinension: length, width and depth. The so-called arrow of time is also a mystery. Paul Davies, in one of his many books, posited that there were three bases for the direction we observe: cosmological, having to do with sequence of the unfolding of the universe; psychological (how are brains perceive the march of time) and entropic, which has to do with the law of entropy that states in a closed system, things inexorably move from a state of high order to lower order. Time is useful for measuring things and as a term of many scientific equations, but I always ask myself: If there were no intelligent life in the universe, would there be such a thing as time? Time is change, but how to account for change has stumped smart people going back to Ancient Greece (I believe Aristotle, at least, struggled to explain it, and believed, I think, there was no such thing as change).

Yes and no. As an irremovable component of spacetime and a variable that appears directly or indirectly in most of the equations of physics, it's as real as anything else that we say exists. The doubtful part of time is our shared experience of a moving present (The Unreality of Time - Wikipedia ). This is likely psychological, but might be impossible to transcend as consciousness has little meaning without it. But even in this worst case, its existence depends on whether the word existence is meant to apply to the world as it seems, or only to a deeper reality that is independent of our observations. It is only to the latter kind of existence that the apparent 'flow' of time might not belong.

Everything that did, could have , or might have occurred in the past along with all that will, may, might, or could happen in the future all happens in the perpetual moment of Now.The reason this question just won't go away is because a century or so ago the good Dr. Einstein conflated space and time in his Theory of Relativity. Atomic clocks add an interesting wrinkle to the conversation.  Optical lattice clocks (OLCs) using ytterbium atoms set a new published record for stability in August 2013 with a precision of 1.6 × 10-18.  At this stability, two such clocks would differ less than a tenth of a second over the age of the universe; this was 10 times better than previous experiments. If time is a figment of our imagination, we seem to be able to measure it with some significant level of precision.  If we could measure ghosts at that level of precision, I might begin to believe in ghosts (wink). To be fair, the purpose of atomic clocks is not so much the measurement of time as it is the establishment of a time standard.  Since time is relative, it is helpful to have a stable standard that we can use to calibrate other clocks, synchronize activities, and accurately measure change.  Since we humans invented a standard that defines the passage of time, in one sense you can say we invented time.  However, just as distance still exists regardless of what units we use to measure it (inches, centimeters, Angstrom units, etc), time exists regardless of the fact that it is relative (the relativity can be measured) and regardless of the arbitrary units we establish to measure it. I'm not necessarily a fan of time, but a universe without would be less eventful.  Ha!

Time does not exist in “Immaterial World”, but as we are part & parcel of the “Material World”, non-static existence of the Universe gives rise to concept of time. Please read further. Let us start from Einstein. He proved that “Everything is Relative”, so time is irrelevant”. Among physicists, there is absolute;y no doubt of their contention that time really & truly exists. Even assuming Einstein is correct, in reality, the time elapsed by movements of planets around the Sun can only be assessed by relative positions of planets & Sun. When we say Einstein was born 138 years back represents time elapsed between his birth day & today. When we say yesterday, today & tomorrow, all these represent some unit of time between any two. When we say there are 24 hours/day & earth takes 365 days to make one complete rotation of Sun, implies that time is involved. It is the time which indicates relative positions of planets. Just imagine(Which is unreal) that planets come to standstill. What happens ? Earth does not rotate on its axis & does not orbit round the Sun. When there is “No event” taking place, what is time which does not exist now. This clearly means that only the relative positions of objects & their movements dictate the need of time to evaluate events. Analysis of time has no real significance, if not related to practical event or incidence. We cannot reinvent lost time. Time at “Present” is zero or non-existent. But taken with reference to the “Past” or with reference to the “Future”, time comes into picture. Our “Consciousness” is single but gets divided due to material manifestation & makes all the difference involving concept of time. Time becomes a means to explain events or incidents at different part of the day. Time is absolutely integral part of the Universe., as long as the Universe is in action & motion. As long as material manifestation is there, concept of time is real. If there is no space, we will not be here & no activity & time has any meaning. Time & Space are interlinked. If there is no space or assumed that a situation before the Universe came into existence, was a single point or nothing was existing, the time did not have any significance or time did not exist. With no activity or event, the time does not exist. Absence of time is a hypothetical case & against universal law. Both time & space are subjective & are not things to count upon. They are our perceptions to describe an event. Time is an indication of interval between any two events. It is also the only indication of moment of change in any action or incident. A plane starts flying from Delhi at a certain moment & lands at Bangalore after a certain period, accounted as “Time of Travel”. A pendulum swings between two extremes of left & right. The period taken for number of swings indicates time to represent as number of swings per minute, simply called as oscillations per minute or “Period of Oscillation”. Time involved between any two events is “Time Interval”. CONCLUSIONS:- In the material world, time exists to account for every incident meaningfully. “With the blessings of Saptha Rishies & Almighty”. No need for diagrams or long scientific discussions. Yes, time exists. As observers, we created it to measure movement. So, yes it's a human construct and nothing "inherent" in the universe. Whether we choose to count it in units (minutes, centuries) or not, as humans perceive motion, there is also a perception of time, likely because we as humans are moving (heart beating, lungs heaving). It's pretty simple. Remove the observer and you can remove time. Or remove motion and you can remove time. But if you do those things no observers will be there to witness the removal of time. So we're stuck with time forever. And that's  long... time.

“Did time really exist?” Do you mean, “Did time really exist before ‘creation’, the big bang, or other beginning of our world and universe? This is a question that turns my head inside-out if I think too much about it. It is a question that neither science, religion nor philosophy has, to my knowledge, ever comprehensively answered. Is time a measurement of the life of the universe? If there was ever no universe (before the Big Bang) then, with nothing to measure, time could be said to have not existed. But for how long did time not exist? Can we measure time retrospectively? A ‘year' is how long the earth takes to complete one orbit of the sun. If there was no sun or earth, were there also no years? Without years, is there any time? For the religious, God created the universe while, before that, there was nothing. On the “first day” God said, “Let there be light” (or words to that effect). So, before the first day, what day was it? Was it 'Zero Day'? How long is zero? If there is a 'zero' or, 'no' day, is there zero or no time? How long was a day before there was the first day? Chronologically, how long was anything if there was nothing? In this scenario, did God have a clock? What were its units of measurement when there wasn't anything to measure? The question keeps folding back in on itself. I confess to not having answered this question. I'll blame it on the question being too 'open' rather than take responsibility for my lack of any definitive answer. I'm following this question in case someone else can answer it properly.

No. I don’t think so. It seems to be a perceptual phenomena that is the result of our form of consciousness. Only matter, space (the absence of matter), and change exist. Because of the way we perceive change in the universe, however, we infer the existence of time. Everything we have that measures what we call “time” is actually a system or device that uses some kind of regularly-recurring change in state as a basis for measurement. (For example: the ticking of a clock, or the vibration of a Cesium atom at a specific temperature) What is real, is the change in state. We infer time from the perceived duration or interval between the changes in state.

This question is as meaningful and useful as the question, "Do submarines swim?" Dependent on the semantic values you stipulate for the linguistic terms "time" and " exist" you can come up with the answer of No. Meanwhile in the real world nobody actually lives their lives as if time does not exist, and for someone to tell you that " time does not exist" because they can, by stipulating their own semantic values for the terms " time" and " exist" conceptualise a theory in which there is no use for propositions such as " time exists" , is as useful and meaningful as them declaring to you that submarines do actually swim.

There are many answers already and I couldn’t read all of them, so if this duplicates an answer, I am sorry. All laws of physics are time reversible except the law of entropy (aka 2nd law of thermodynamics): Second law of thermodynamics - Wikipedia Which essentially states that all closed systems will become more disordered with time. This fundamentally defines the direction of the arrow of time. This is also why heat flows from a hotter body to a colder body, unless energy is provided to pump the heat in the opposite direction. This is why we all wear out (age) with time. So to answer your question, time exists - or else I could go back to being young again!

There are two opposite positions in science about the real existence of time. The books by Julian Barbour “The end of Time” and by Lee Smolin “The rebirth of Time” are two enjoyable divulgative books by two scientists who, despite haveing opposite ideas, in their books mention each other with respect. Way batter than what Newton and Leibniz did. In brief: Barbour considers the spacetime as a potentially infinite set of “slices” that one can perceive as continuous, like the photograms of a movie. This is not a very new idea, but he starts from geometry to explain how it can be possible. On the other side, Smolin denies the non-existence of time and mentions a number of reasons why Time must have a real existence, not just being a consequence of the thermodynamics laws. Nobody has an answer, but you can make your own opinion after reading both those books. My prefeerence goes to Barbour but it’s just a question of personal tastes.

In my mind, I think time is best described as a measure of change. Subjective time seems to follow this definition; when you are busy (lots of changes) then time flies, whereas when when in a boring environment (not much change) time seems to crawl. Also; how would you detect if time ‘stopped’? It would look like a freeze-frame in a movie i.e. no detectable changes. When folk say that ‘time started’ at the Big Bang maybe it was because it came from a void where time wasn’t measurable (and therefore didn’t exist) because nothing was changing. If time has an end, it will come at the point where change in the Universe permanently ceases. The ultimate ‘freeze-frame’!

I have often pondered on my own relationship with Time. I do not wear a watch because I would always be looking at it, but never know what time it is. Yet, I am seldom late for appointments because I innately factor in extra time. Time is an abstract concept that has been constrained to calendars and clocks. My personal theory is that time is not linear. The past is gone, therefore it no longer exists. The future has not yet happened, therefore it does not yet exist. Within this paradigm, time can only exist in the present. Einstein was inspired when he discovered the relativity of time.

Yes time does exist. Time is an aspect or feature of energy. It is the duration or measure of the motion of energy. The motion of energy causes things to either progress or regress, grow or decompose, generate or degenerate. As we observe change in matter, even our experience as matter, we sense the concept of time elapsing because of the ever motion of energy. If energy were to stop moving, which it never truly does, time would also stop. Despite popular terminology there is no “arrow of time” as if time moves in a certain direction. It is energy and matter that can move in certain directions. Time is not the measure of the direction in which energy may be moving but simply its positional motion, that is its vibration. The sense of past, present and future is our sense of the passage of time as it has lapsed, is elapsing and know it will elapse, though time is not actually moving in any direction. Time moving in a direction is a conception of the mind, but time does exist.

As far as we can tell, time is essentially entropy. Here is a great youtube series from Minute Physics explaining this idea. The gist of it is that every observed law of nature that we can see doesn't really have a time preference. The math for gravity, electromagnetism, etc work just as well forward and backward in time. The thing that changes with time is entropy, that is, things get more disordered going from past to future. It is entirely possible that time as we perceive it is simply an after effect of the general level of disorder increasing.

Time is only a highly abstract concept created by human minds to capture the fact, that change in the universe takes place in a certain sequence (dependent or independent phenomena). Causality is what connects phenomena in reality, not a time flow. Nevertheless, the causality is mostly so complex, that we are not able to perceive it, the less understand it. We just perceive the sequence of phenomena and because do not understand the causal links, we believe they happen in a certain sequence. To describe the sequence we need the concept of time.The naturally observed categories “before” and “after” (when perceiving relations between individual phenomena) required sooner or later also a kind of ability to express the measure “how much after X?” and later also in the opposite logic “how much before Y?”. It made the mind to perceive a permanently flowing sequence. For practical reasons of thinking and later also of communication, a certain measure was necessary, first, the natural one (day and night periods, year season periods), later human-made ones, such as converting periodical pendulum moves to the clock-hand rotation on a numbered dial etc.

Time has objective reality in the sense that two separate observers measuring the same interval (and within the same reference frame) between events can agree on values.  In that sense, its reality has a character similar to mathematics in which different practitioners working a well defined problem can reach and agree on a common answer--even using different methods.
